10.05.text: NASA's Swift and ESA's XMM-Newton satellites

14.09.text: have used their X-ray telescopes to watch the interaction between a pair of gigantic

18.12.text: stars. This is a stellar grouping called Cygnus OB2,

22.15.text: one of the richest collections of hot, massive O-type stars in the

26.18.text: galaxy. Unfortunately for optical astronomers, this spectacular

30.23.text: sight is mostly hidden by dust clouds. One of these stars

34.29.text: is a radio source simply called Cygnus OB2 number 9.

38.35.text: In 2008, astronomers concluded that the changes in radio emission only made

42.41.text: sense if the star were actually a binary, with two massive stars in a tight

46.42.text: orbit. Massive stars run so hot that they

50.45.text: actually drive away some of their gas in powerful outflows called stellar winds.

54.47.text: In binaries with two large young stars orbiting closely,

58.50.text: these hot outflows collide and produce X-rays. Only a few

62.50.text: of these colliding wind systems are known, and they aren't especially well behaved for

66.53.text: astronomers. The collision may become turbulent, and X-rays may appear only

70.55.text: at some times in the orbit. Which brings us back to Cygnus OB2 number

74.57.text: nine. It should produce X-rays where the stars' winds collide, but there was

78.59.text: no evidence for it. Perhaps it only occurred when the stars were closest in

82.62.text: their 2.4-year orbit. The first opportunity to test this came

86.65.text: during the close approach on June 28, 2011. So astronomers

90.67.text: enlisted Swift and XMM-Newton, as well as ground-based observatories to monitor

94.69.text: the system at intervals throughout the year. As the stars approach each other,

98.71.text: their fierce winds crash together at several million miles an hour, reaching temperatures

102.75.text: of millions of degrees and creating X-rays. As they separate,

106.77.text: the collision strength decreases. Even so, these powerful winds

110.82.text: will influence star formation in the binary's neighborhood.

114.84.text: Cygnus OB2 number nine has turned out to be a

118.88.text: model colliding wind binary, one of the most reliable and best behaved now known.

122.90.text: It will be a key to better understanding how these systems
